content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. An object of mass <math alttext="4.0 kilograms"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. A conservative force is exerted on the object. The potential energy <math alttext="U"><mstyle><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> associated with this force is given as a function of position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by the equation <math alttext="U of x equals K x cubed plus L x squared plus M x plus N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>M</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="K equals negative 2 joules per cubic meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="L equals 10 joules per square meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M equals negative 5 joules per meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="N equals 4 joules"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. This function is shown in the graph provided. The kinetic energy of the object when <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is 20 <math alttext="joules"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Calculate the speed of the object when it is at <math alttext="x equals 2 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. An object of mass <math alttext="4.0 kilograms"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. A conservative force is exerted on the object. The potential energy <math alttext="U"><mstyle><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> associated with this force is given as a function of position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by the equation <math alttext="U of x equals K x cubed plus L x squared plus M x plus N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>M</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="K equals negative 2 joules per cubic meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="L equals 10 joules per square meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M equals negative 5 joules per meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="N equals 4 joules"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. This function is shown in the graph provided. The kinetic energy of the object when <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is 20 <math alttext="joules"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Calculate the speed of the object when it is at <math alttext="x equals 2 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Does the object reach <math alttext="x equals 3 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? ____ Yes ____ No Justify your answer.

(c) Is the force acting on the object positive, negative, or zero between <math alttext="x equals 1 meter"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 2 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? _____ Positive _____ Negative _____ Zero Justify your answer.

(d) Calculate the acceleration of the object when it is at <math alttext="x equals 1.5 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) On the graph above, draw a dot at the position where the maximum negative force is exerted on the object. Provide your reasoning.

(f) When the object passes the origin, it is moving in the <math alttext="positive x"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction with a kinetic energy of 20 <math alttext="joules"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Will the object ever return to the origin? ____ Yes ____ No Provide your reasoning.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
